questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Ostmann’s pad of fat is seen at lateral semicircular canal
  2. Crus commune is formed by the union of superior and posterior semicircular canal.
  3. Singular nerve is a branch of inferior vestibular nerve
  4. Recruitment is a feature of retrocochlear lesions
questions.solution: Ans. B. 2,3

questions.text: A patient says that he feels that there is something wrong with him mentally and it is because of the summer season. How much would he score on the insight scale?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3

 

On the standard scale of insight used in psychiatry, a score of three indicates that the patient recognizes that something is wrong with them but attributes it to an external or non-psychological cause. In this case, the patient admits that there is a mental problem but explains it away by blaming the summer season. This shows partial awareness of illness but with incorrect attribution, which corresponds to level three on the insight scale.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2: A score of two reflects complete denial of illness. The patient does not acknowledge that anything is wrong with them. This does not match the vignette since the patient has admitted something is wrong.

 

Option C. 4: A score of four indicates that the patient recognizes that they are ill but attributes it to psychological or emotional causes rather than a medical or psychiatric disorder. The vignette does not show this, because the patient attributes the problem to summer season, not to psychological stress.

 

Option D. 5: A score of five reflects true insight, where the patient accepts that they have a mental disorder and recognizes the need for treatment. The patient here does not have this level of awareness, so five is not correct.

 

Grades of INSIGHT: 

 

Level 1 – Complete denial of illness

 

  • Example: A psychotic patient who insists nothing is wrong despite severe symptoms.

 

Level 2 – Slight awareness but denies illness

 

  • Example: “I am just tired, not sick.”

 

Level 3 – Acknowledges illness but explains it away by blaming external factors.

 

  • Example: “I feel mentally unwell, but it is because of the summer heat.”

 

Level 4 – Recognizes illness due to psychological causes

 

  • Example: “I am mentally disturbed because of tension at work.”

 

Level 5 – Recognizes mental illness but reluctant to take treatment

 

  • Example: “Yes, I may have depression, but I do not think I need medicines.”

 

Level 6 – True emotional insight

 

  • This is the highest level of insight.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department after sustaining an accidental penetrating injury to the left. Examination shows left globe perforation with decreased visual acuity. The right eye is normal. Surgical treatment is performed with subsequent improvement in vision. Two months later, the patient experiences pain, photophobia, and diminished vision in the right eye. Evaluation shows leukocytes in the anterior chamber and vitreous humor and choroidal deposits consistent with granulomatous panuveitis. Disruption of which of the following immune processes is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Immune privilege

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman brings her stepson to the OPD for a well-child visit. She never wanted children due to her unhappy childhood and wishes her marriage did not include being a stepmother to her husband's 5-year-old son. In the waiting room, the woman seems excessively concerned when the boy accidentally trips and is clearly uninjured. During the visit, she tells the physician that she adores the child and describes her elaborate preparations for his birthday party. Which of the following defense mechanisms best explains this woman's behavior?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Reaction formation

questions.text: A 20-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department for difficulty breathing. The patient has had rhinorrhea and nasal congestion for the past 2 days. She developed a cough and noisy breathing this evening. Medical history is otherwise negative. On examination, the patient has suprasternal and intercostal retractions, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough. Inflammation and edema of which of the following sites is most likely causing this patient's stridor?
questions.solution: Ans. D. F

questions.text: What does the given image represent?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Hypnogram

choices.text: Illness anxiety disorder

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate due to significant left leg weakness. The symptom began 3 days ago after her father had a heart attack. There is no personal or family history of neurological disease; surgical history includes liposuction of the thighs and varicose vein removal. Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 123/81 mm Hg, pulse is 62/min, and respirations are 14/min. Physical examination reveals symmetric 2+ deep tendon reflexes as well as normal muscle bulk and tone bilaterally in the upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Conversion disorder

choices.text: Cochlear nucleus → olivary complex medial → lateral geniculate body → inferior colliculus
Cochlear nucleus → olivary complex inferior → lateral lemniscus → inferior geniculate body
Cochlear nucleus → olivary complex superior → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus
Cochlear nucleus → olivary complex lateral → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of auditory pathway
questions.solution: Ans. C. Cochlear necleus → olivary complex superior → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a history of bipolar disorder is brought to the emergency department by his wife. He has been unable to sleep for more than 3 hours a night for the past week. Over the past several weeks, the patient has been irritable at home and has argued constantly with his wife. He has racing thoughts and speaks rapidly. The patient has stopped going to his job having decided to stay home and "unravel the secrets of the universe." He has been drawing shapes and equations on the walls, and he has accused his wife of working for the police and trying to steal his secrets. Prior to examination, the patient becomes increasingly agitated and is hospitalized against his will. He is prescribed multiple medications to address his symptoms. Five days later, the patient is calm but has difficulty moving spontaneously or getting out of bed. He does not respond appropriately to questions and appears newly disoriented and confused. Temperature is 39.4 C (102.9 F), blood pressure is 162/98 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 20/min. Dysregulation of which of the following neurotransmitters is most likely to be the primary cause of this patient's new symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Dopamine

choices.text: Fibrovascular cores surrounded by squamous epithelium
Glandular structures with droplets of mucin
Inflammatory infiltrate with pseudo-hyphae
Irregular nests of cells with keratinization

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the OPD due to worsening difficulty with swallowing food over the last 3 months. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. On examination, there is a firm, palpable mass at the base of tongue. Cervical lymph nodes are also palpable. Which of the following histologic features is most likely to be seen on biopsy of the tongue lesion?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Irregular nests of cells with keratinization

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Ans. A) A3, B4, C1, D2

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to your clinic by her daughter. The daughter is concerned about her mother's recent behaviour. She reports that her mother seems to be experiencing visual hallucinations, frequently talking to people who aren't there and becoming startled by things she claims to see, but which aren't present. The daughter denies any history of psychiatric disorders in her mother. The patient's medications include atorvastatin and a daily multivitamin. Her blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following symptoms is most suggestive of an organic aetiology for the patient's behavioral changes?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Prominent visual hallucinations

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. However, she says that he has been complaining of intermittent headaches, memory loss, and vision disturbances for the past 2 weeks. Brain imaging shows a solitary mass within the right temporal lobe. Which of the following visual field defects (areas of vision loss in black) is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B

choices.text: Brief psychotic disorder

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman comes to the OPD at her mother's urging due to irritability and low mood. Two months ago, the patient was sexually assaulted in the parking lot of her workplace. Since then, she has felt that "the world is not a safe place" and is reluctant to go back to work, preferring to stay home. In the middle of the day she will

"space out" and hear the voice of her assailant, "as if I am right there in the parking lot." At other times, she feels a sense of unreality as if she is outside her body and cannot recall the exact details about what happened, and says that, "I feel like I am going crazy." The patient has become withdrawn and either avoids her friends or becomes

"snappy" when they visit her. She has lost interest in her hobbies of writing poetry and exercising. There is a family history of major depression in the patient's mother and schizoaffective disorder in her maternal grandmother. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B. PTSD

choices.text: Conductive loss in both ears
Conductive loss in left ear
Conductive loss in right ear
Sensorineural loss in both ears

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to difficulty hearing for the past few weeks. During the neurologic examination, the physician assesses her hearing using a vibrating tuning fork. The handle of the tuning fork is placed on her left mastoid process until the sound is no longer audible. The tines are then quickly placed near the patient's left auditory meatus, and she reports hearing no sound. When the handle of the vibrating fork is placed on the middle of her forehead, she hears the vibration more strongly in her left ear than her right. This patient is most likely experiencing which of the following types of hearing loss?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Conductive loss in left ear

questions.text: Mutism and akinesis in a person who is aware of his surroundings and somewhat alert is best described as a feature of:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Stupor

choices.text: Gradual onset of symptoms
Predominantly positive symptoms
Onset before the age of 20

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man with schizophrenia comes to the OPD for follow-up. The patient has been stable on his antipsychotic medication for many years. He has infrequent auditory hallucinations and says that the medication

"has helped a lot to turn down the volume of the voices." His symptoms first developed gradually at age 14 when he exhibited nonspecific anxiety and became increasingly paranoid that others were talking about him behind his back; he also became preoccupied with finding special meanings in certain numbers. A year later he was hospitalized for a psychotic episode characterized by paranoid delusions and auditory hallucinations that responded rapidly to antipsychotic medication. The patient was able to finish high school. He was hospitalized again briefly at age 22 but has remained out of the hospital since then. Which of the following factors is most predictive of a favorable prognosis for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Predominantly positive symptoms

questions.text: Development of saccule of membranous labyrinth is from:
questions.solution: Ans. D. Pars inferior

choices.text: Low risk of dependence
Low risk of respiratory depression

questions.text: 24-year-old man comes to the OPD for treatment of opioid use disorder. The patient has a 6-year history of heroin use. His boss has spoken to him about his erratic moods and inconsistent work performance, and he is now in danger of losing his job. The patient asks for help, saying, "I have tried so hard to do this on my own. I don't want to use, but the craving is so strong." The physician refers the patient to an opioid treatment program where he is started on maintenance therapy with methadone. During the next followup appointment, he reports a marked reduction in his cravings. Which of the following properties of the administered drug is most likely responsible for the improvement in this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Long half-life

choices.text: Elevated endolymphatic hydrostatic pressure
Elevated hydrostatic pressure in the middle ear
Loose semicircular canal debris

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the OPD due to feeling "dizzy" over the past 2 weeks.He works in a warehouse and says he experiences a brief, severe spinning sensation when looking up at objects on a high shelf. Examination shows normal hearing. Ocular movements in a sitting position are normal, but when the patient's head is rotated to the right side off the examination table, he develops vertigo and rotatory nystagmus. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Loose semicircular canal debris

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to your office for follow-up after a recent below-the-knee amputation secondary to complications from diabetes. He reports an unusual sensation where he feels that his amputated leg is still present. He even experiences pain in the non-existent limb. Considering this scenario, this patient's phantom limb experience is best classified as a disorder of:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Perception

questions.text: Temperatures used in bithermal caloric test (in degree Celsius):
questions.solution: Ans. A. 30 and 44

choices.text: Decreased bicarbonate formation in ciliary body
Decreased formation of abnormal blood vessels in retina

questions.text: A 58-year-old airline captain comes to the OPD after he was found to have abnormal vision testing during a pilot medical certification examination. The patient feels well and has no ocular symptoms. Vision testing shows normal visual acuity but moderate loss of peripheral vision in both eyes. Results of the funduscopic examination are shown in the image below. He is started on latanoprost eyedrops. The medication is most likely to improve this patient's condition through which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Increased outflow of aqueous humor

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman comes to the OPD for a yearly checkup. The patient has no medical conditions but expresses dissatisfaction with her appearance and wishes she could lose weight more easily. She reports occasional constipation and fatigue. Weight is 58.1 kg (128 lb) and height is 157.5 cm (5 ft 2 in). BMI is 23.4 kg/m2.

Routine laboratory evaluation shows a potassium level of 3.1 mEq/L. Physical examination is most likely to show which of the following abnormalities?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Parotid enlargement

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after a seizure. The patient reports pain on the left side of her face and is unable to fully open or close her mouth. She is drooling. On examination, the jaw deviates to the right and the left mandibular condyle is very prominent with a palpable depression posterior to it. The patient is diagnosed with an anterior dislocation of the left temporomandibular joint. The jaw is most likely maintained in a dislocated position due to continued spasm of which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lateral pterygoid

 

The muscle responsible for maintaining the jaw in an anteriorly dislocated temporomandibular joint (TMJ) position is the lateral pterygoid. Spasm of the lateral pterygoid pulls the mandibular condyle and articular disc anteriorly, preventing the jaw from closing properly in acute TMJ dislocation cases.

 

  • The lateral pterygoid muscle inserts onto the neck of the mandibular condyle and the articular disc, and its contraction produces forward (anterior) movement of the condyle.
  • When the mandible is dislocated anteriorly, the lateral pterygoid may enter into spasm and hold the condyle in the dislocated position, making reduction difficult until the spasm resolves

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Buccinator: Involved in cheek compression; does not move the condyle or disc of the TMJ.

 

Option B. Genioglossus: Primarily protrudes the tongue; not involved in TMJ articulation.

 

Option D. Sternocleidomastoid: Functions to turn and flex the neck; does not act on the mandible or TMJ

choices.text: Reactive mood response to positive stimulus
Responds better to TCAs than MAO-I and SSRI

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of atypical depression?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Responds better to TCAs than MAO-I and SSRI

 

Atypical depression is a subtype of major depressive disorder that differs from the classic “melancholic” type by having mood reactivity (the ability to feel better temporarily in response to positive events) and distinct biological features. Like typical depression, patients with atypical depression respond best to SSRIs, rather than TCAs and MAO-Is.

 

Key Features of Atypical Depression:

 

  1. Mood reactivity – Mood improves in response to positive events or good news.
  2. Increased sleep (hypersomnia) – Unlike classic depression, where insomnia is more common.
  3. Increased appetite and weight gain – “Comfort eating” or carbohydrate craving.
  4. Leaden paralysis – A sensation of heaviness in the arms and legs.
  5. Rejection sensitivity – Overly sensitive to perceived interpersonal rejection or criticism.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to worsening anxiety and insomnia over the past 3 months. She says, "I'm really worried that something is wrong with me. I was never a particularly anxious person, but now I feel anxious all the time. Sometimes I feel panicky for no reason; my heart races and I break out in a sweat. The only benefit is that I have lost 5 pounds (2.3 kg) without even trying." Blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg and pulse is 112/min. On physical examination, the patient is restless and has warm, moist skin and mild hand tremor bilaterally. Mental status examination is notable for a frightened stare, anxious mood, and rapid speech. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Anxiety caused by a medical condition

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Ans. C. A4, B2, C1, D3

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia is brought to the clinic by her parents after attempting to drink rubbing alcohol in response to voices telling her to kill herself. The patient believes that a television newscaster is sending her secret messages and that the devil injects her with poison at night while she is sleeping. She first developed symptoms at age 23 and has had 7 previous psychiatric hospitalizations and 2 suicide attempts. Trials of haloperidol, risperidone, and olanzapine have yielded minimal improvement. Her medical conditions include hypertension and mild obesity. Medication therapy with clozapine is initiated. Which of the following should be regularly monitored in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Absolute neutrophil count

choices.text: Acute middle ear effusion with concurrent tympanic membrane inflammation
Chronic foreign body impaction with external ear canal abrasion
External ear canal epithelial maceration and inflammation
Tympanic membrane epithelium and keratin debris accumulation

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to persistent ear discharge. The patient began to have purulent right ear drainage a month ago. Topical antibiotic drops and oral antibiotics have not improved his symptoms. He has had no fever, ear pain, dizziness, or tinnitus.  There is scant, yellow, malodorous discharge in the right ear canal. The right tympanic membrane (TM) is immobile with insufflation and appears intact. There is retraction of the superior portion of the TM and a pearly white mass. Audiometry reveals conductive hearing loss on the right side. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Tympanic membrane epithelium and keratin debris accumulation

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of complicated cataracts?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Krukenberg spindle

 

Krukenberg spindle is not a feature of complicated cataract.
It refers to a vertical, spindle-shaped deposit of pigment on the posterior surface of the cornea (endothelium), typically seen in pigment dispersion syndrome or pigmentary glaucoma, not in cataracts.

 

The pigment originates from the posterior surface of the iris and gets deposited on the corneal endothelium due to aqueous convection currents.

 

Thus, while it’s an ophthalmic finding, it is unrelated to complicated cataract formation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polychromatic lustre: Seen in complicated cataracts, where the lens shows multicolored reflexes when illuminated due to changes in refractive index of degenerating lens fibers. This iridescent appearance is a hallmark of chronic inflammatory cataract.

 

 

Option C. Occurs after uveitis: Complicated cataract develops secondary to chronic intraocular inflammation, especially anterior uveitis, iridocyclitis, or retinitis. Inflammation alters lens metabolism leading to opacification — hence, this is a classic cause.

 

Option D. Breadcrumb appearance: Refers to irregular, grayish-white opacities in the posterior subcapsular region of the lens — characteristic of complicated cataract due to inflammatory deposits resembling “bread crumbs.”

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate brought to the outpatient department is found to have bilateral conjunctivitis. Chest X-ray done showed lung infiltrates. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the infection?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Chlamydia trachomatis

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the OPD for follow-up of hypertension. At his last appointment, he revealed that he had increased his intake of cans of beer from 3 to 6 cans daily due to stress at work. The physician advised him to seek help for his alcohol use because it could be causing his elevated blood pressure and has many negative health risks. The patient now tells the physician, "I thought about what you said. I know my alcohol use has gotten out of hand and is affecting my health. My wife and daughter also say that I need to quit. I have made an appointment with a counselor to talk about my options." Which of the following best describes this patient's stage of behavioral change?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preparation

 

In the preparation stage of the transtheoretical model of behavior change, the individual recognizes the problem, intends to take action soon, and often begins making small steps toward change. In this case, the patient admits that his drinking is a problem, acknowledges the health impact, accepts family concern, and has already scheduled an appointment with a counselor. This shows he is preparing actively to quit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Action: The action stage involves overt behavior change, such as the patient already quitting alcohol or reducing intake. In this scenario, he has not yet stopped drinking, so he has not reached the action stage.

 

Option B. Contemplation: In this stage, the patient recognizes there may be a problem and considers change but has not committed or made concrete steps. An example would be a patient saying, “I know drinking might not be good for me, but I’m not sure I’m ready to stop.” Our patient has gone beyond this by taking a specific step toward change.

 

Option C. Precontemplation: In this stage, the patient denies having a problem and does not intend to change. For example, a patient might say, “My drinking is not a problem; I can handle it.” The man in this vignette clearly acknowledges his alcohol use is harmful, so this stage does not fit.

choices.text: Central retinal artery occlusion

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of poor medical follow-up comes to the OPD due to difficulty seeing. He has had blurry vision for the last 2 weeks. A day ago, he noticed a shadow develop suddenly across the visual field of his right eye. Visual field testing by confrontation reveals patchy loss of vision. A flame-shaped retinal hemorrhage in the right eye is noted on funduscopic examination, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his visual disturbance?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Hypertension

questions.text: A 24-month-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother due to concerns about walking. The mother says, "She seems so unsteady when she walks. She was walking so well until a few weeks ago, and now she keeps tripping over things." On examination, the patient is sitting on the floor and clapping her hands. She does not answer questions and instead makes babbling sounds. Height and weight track at the 50th percentile. At a checkup 6 months ago, the patient had been saying 1 or 2 word phrases and walking without aid. Which of the following neuropathic changes most likely underlies this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arrested brain development

 

This child shows normal early development followed by regression of acquired motor and language milestones. She was walking independently and using simple words at eighteen months but has now lost these skills. The scenario is highly suggestive of Rett syndrome, a neurodevelopmental disorder seen almost exclusively in girls. The underlying neuropathology in Rett syndrome is arrested brain development with deceleration of head growth, not true neurodegeneration. The disease is due to mutations in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Accumulation of hyperphosphorylated tau protein: This is characteristic of Alzheimer disease and some other dementias. It causes progressive memory decline in older adults, not developmental regression in a toddler.

 

Option C. Copper deposition in the lenticular nucleus: This describes Wilson disease, which typically presents in older children or young adults with liver disease, psychiatric symptoms, and movement disorders. It does not cause early childhood regression of milestones as seen here.

 

Option D. Cortical hyperexpansion: This is associated with developmental brain overgrowth disorders such as autism spectrum disorder, where children may show accelerated early head growth. In Rett syndrome, by contrast, head growth decelerates due to arrested development, not hyperexpansion.

questions.text:
Identify the true statements

  1. Multiple perforations seen in tubercular otitis media
  2. Pars flaccida is weaker due to absence of mucosal layer
  3. Handle of malleus is foreshortened in retracted tympanic membrane
  4. Incus long process has got no muscular attachments
questions.solution: Ans. B. 1,3,4

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Ans. C. A2, B3, C1, D4

questions.text: The following device is used for all of the following indications except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Corneal tattooing

 

The image shows a stenopaic slit (stenopaic disc) — a diagnostic ophthalmic device consisting of a black circular disc with a narrow slit in the center.


The slit allows light to pass only through a specific meridian of the eye, helping to evaluate refractive errors.

 

This device is not used for corneal tattooing, which involves pigmentation of the cornea for cosmetic or optical purposes.

 

Hence, option C is the correct answer (the exception).

 

  • Corneal tattooing (keratopigmentation) is a surgical cosmetic procedure to hide corneal scars or leukomas or to reduce glare in aniridia.

 

Uses pigments or dyes, not optical devices like the stenopaic slit

 

Uses of the Stenopaic Slit

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man hospitalized for acute cholecystitis is being evaluated for anxiety and agitation. He underwent an open cholecystectomy without having any operative complications. Two days after admission, the patient experiences anxiety and tremulousness, and he becomes irritable, severely agitated, and verbally abusive to the nursing staff. The patient does not use tobacco or illicit drugs but admits to drinking 6-8 beers daily for the last several years. Blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg and pulse is 110/min. Examination shows hand tremors bilaterally.

Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Chlordiazepoxide

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman with Alzheimer dementia is brought to the OPD for evaluation of new-onset drooling. She has also been very tearful over the past 2 weeks, particularly at night when she wakes up crying and clutching her ear. The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus that requires insulin and multiple medications. Her last hemoglobin A1c was 8.5%. Temperature is 38°C (100.4 °F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination of the right ear canal shows granulation tissue with a surrounding white drainage in the floor of the canal. The tympanic membrane is clear and mobile to pneumatic otoscopy. There is facial asymmetry with some downward deviation of the right corner of the mouth. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism for this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

questions.text: A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological examination to exclude possibility of
questions.solution: Ans. B. Sebaceous cell carcinoma

questions.text: A patient came to the ophthalmology OPD with corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, corneal perforation and foreign body. Which of the following will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Suprachoroidal hemorrhage

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was hospitalized for a psychotic episode in which he heard voices of God and the devil and believed that his family was plotting to kill him. He improved rapidly with medication therapy and was discharged. Three months later, the patient comes to the emergency department due to generalized muscle stiffness and shaking of his right hand. He has no other medical history and takes no other medications. Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, pulse is 68/min, and respirations are 14/min. On mental status examination, he is alert and oriented with mild paranoia but no auditory hallucinations. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Benztropine

choices.text: Absence of the left corneal reflex
Drooping of the left eyelid
Inability to close the left eye
Inward deviation of the left eye

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to double vision. The patient first experienced difficulty focusing her eyes while at work yesterday. On awakening this morning, her symptoms had progressed to frank diplopia.  Medical history is insignificant. A complete physical examination is performed, including a full neurologic assessment. Shining light into the patient's right eye causes constriction of her right pupil, but not the left pupil. Shining light into her left eye causes constriction of only her right pupil. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Drooping of the left eyelid

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to ataxia and tremor. The patient's symptoms started gradually 2 weeks ago and have worsened acutely over the past 2 days. She is having difficulty walking and almost fell while getting up from a chair. The patient's medical problems include bipolar disorder and recently diagnosed hypertension. Her medications include a stable dose of lithium for many years and a new blood pressure medication that was started several weeks ago. Neurologic examination reveals a resting tremor and difficulty with balance. A drug interaction involving which of the following medications is most likely causing this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. ﻿ D. Hydrochlorothiazide

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia. This increases on extroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Right superior rectus

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the histopathological image of retina.
questions.solution: Ans. A. Drusen

choices.text: Horizontal portion of facial nerve on the medial wall of middle ear
Vertical portion of facial nerve on the posterior wall of middle ear
In the parotid substance where it divides into its 5 terminal branches

questions.text: A patient with post traumatic facial nerve palsy has presented with absent taste sensation on anterior 2/3rd part of his tongue. His stapedial reflex was checked and it was absent. Schirmer’s test for lacrimation was done and it was negative .i.e., lacrimation was normal. Most probable site of facial nerve lesion could be at
questions.solution: Ans. B. Horizontal portion of facial nerve on the medial wall of middle ear

choices.text: Brief psychotic disorder
Major depression with psychotic features

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being found sitting in the street drinking his own urine. The patients mother says that a year ago he expressed the belief that he was being watched by an unidentified government agency and subsequently broke up with his girlfriend, quit his job, and disconnected his phone. The patient's mother has noticed that he no longer seems to care about activities that used to interest him, and last month she found out that he had moved into the family garden shed with his dog. On examination, the patient is malodorous, disheveled, and laughs for no apparent reason. He later becomes angry and refuses to sit in a chair for the interview. The patient switches among unrelated topics and when asked where he lives says, "in the holy buffet of diplomacy." Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 122/79 mm Hg, and pulse is 80/min. Physical examination and laboratory evaluation, including urine toxicology, are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. ﻿﻿D. Schizophrenia

choices.text: Demyelination in the CNS
Increased volume of endolymph in the inner ear
Inflammation of the vestibular labyrinth
Mass lesion at the cerebellopontine angle

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to dizziness. She has a 6-month history of episodic bouts where she experiences a spinning sensation associated with nausea and ringing in her left ear. The patient also has difficulty hearing while holding her phone to the left ear, although hearing in the right ear is normal. The dizziness improves spontaneously, and she feels fine between episodes. Past medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, for which she is on thyroid replacement therapy, and endometriosis, which led to a hysterectomy at age 38. The patient works as a supermarket manager. She does not use tobacco or drink alcohol. This patient's condition is most likely the result of which of the following pathologic processes?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Increased volume of endolymph in the inner ear

questions.text: The spectacles shown in the image are not used for the management of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypermetropia

 

The spectacles in the image show plus (convex) lenses with magnifying effect and a characteristic ring scotoma (jack-in-the-box effect) — typical of high-power convex lenses used for aphakia or presbyopia correction.

 

However, these thick convex lenses are not routinely used for hypermetropia because:

 

  • Hypermetropia requires low-power convex lenses, not these high-magnification aphakic-type glasses.
  • The lenses shown are bifocals or high-plus aphakic glasses, designed for near vision correction, not simple refractive hypermetropia.

 

Thus, these spectacles are not used for hypermetropia management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presbyopia: Used.

 

  • Bifocal lenses (as seen in image) are standard for presbyopia, where near vision is impaired due to loss of accommodation.
  • Upper segment: distance correction
  • Lower segment: near correction

 

Option B. Aphakia: Used.

 

  • Aphakia (absence of crystalline lens) leads to high hypermetropia (+10 D to +12 D).
  • Managed using high-power convex lenses (thick magnifying lenses) or intraocular lens implantation.
  • These glasses cause ring scotoma, image magnification , and prismatic aberrations — typical of the lenses shown.

 

Option C. Pediatric pseudophakia: Used.

 

  • Children who undergo IOL implantation for congenital cataract (pseudophakia) often need spectacles with bifocal add to aid near vision (since IOL is monofocal).
  • The spectacles shown could serve that role — distance + near correction in one frame.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the OPD due to depression. He feels sad and unmotivated, sleeps 12 hours a day, and has increased appetite, poor concentration at work, and fleeting thoughts of suicide. Major depressive disorder is diagnosed, and antidepressant medication administered. Several weeks after starting the medication, the patient's depressive symptoms are mildly improved, but he is now distressed by a significant decrease in libido and impaired sexual performance. He is considering stopping the medication and requests an alternate treatment. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Bupropion

questions.text: Physical examination of a 23-year-old man diagnosed with chronic hepatitis shows corneal changes that are visible to the naked eye, as shown in the image below. This patient is most likely to have which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Basal ganglia atrophy

choices.text: Distortion of corneal reflex at center

questions.text: In Keratoconus all are seen except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Hypermetropic refractive error found

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the OPD with new-onset low back pain. The patient was helping her friend move yesterday and strained her back. Medical history includes hypertension and major depressive disorder currently treated with captopril and citalopram. A short course of medication is prescribed, and the patient is asked to monitor for development of diaphoresis, restlessness, tremors, and diarrhea. The patient was most likely prescribed which of the following medications?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Tramadol

questions.text:
Which of these options are considered direct gonioscopes?

 

  1. Goldmann
  2. Richardson
  3. Zeis
  4. Koeppe
questions.solution: Ans. B. 2, 4

questions.text: A man diagnosed with schizophrenia has been admitted to the psychiatric ward for inpatient management. One day, a nurse enters his room for routine checks, but he unexpectedly reacts with aggression, physically assaulting the nurse. Furthermore, he accuses her of being his actual wife in disguise and blames her for administering incorrect medications. Based on this scenario, which type of delusional misidentification syndrome is most likely being displayed by this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Fregoli syndrome

questions.text:
Identify the causes of sensorineural hearing loss:

 

  1. Acoustic neuroma
  2. Presbycusis
  3. Meniere’s disease
  4. Superior semicircular dehiscence syndrome
questions.solution: Ans. B. 1,2,3

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the OPD for evaluation of discomfort in his wrists. He thinks his symptoms may be related to "typing all day, every day." The patient is a software engineer and prefers to work remotely from home to "avoid wasting time talking and interacting with coworkers." He rarely leaves his apartment and spends his spare time on his computer, reading online forums about space exploration and the possibility of alien life. When asked about relationships he says, "I've always liked being on my own." He spent a large portion of his childhood disassembling and rebuilding electronic devices and had few friends. His affect appears constricted and his responses to questions are limited. Which of the following is the most likely personality disorder in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Schizoid

choices.text: Apply ice packs to the nose and recommend NSAIDs
Embolize the sphenopalatine artery
﻿﻿﻿Incise and drain the nasal septum
﻿﻿﻿Insert anterior nasal packing

questions.text: 22-year-old man comes to the urgent care clinic after being hit in the face with a basketball. He had bleeding from both sides of his nose for about 10 minutes that stopped with pressure. He is currently unable to breathe through his nose. Medical history is significant for allergic rhinitis treated with oral antihistamines. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 70/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On examination, there is bruising across the nose and under the eyes. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals no bleeding. There is soft, fluctuant swelling of the septum bilaterally. There is no blood in the oropharynx. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C. ﻿﻿﻿Incise and drain the nasal septum

choices.text: It is called Argyll Robertson pupil
The vision is normal in right eye
Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the image given below:
questions.solution: Ans. D. Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes

choices.text: Orbital A-V fistula

questions.text: A 23-year old male presents with progressive proptosis of his right eye. The proptosis increases on bending forward and is compressible. No thrill or bruit was present. Orbital ultrasound revealed an echogenic mass with foci of echo shadows. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Orbital varix

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Super supraglottic swallow

choices.text: Tumor necrosis factor-alpha
Vascular endothelial growth factor

questions.text: A 67-year-old smoker comes to the OPD with a 2-week history of decreased vision in his right eye that he describes as "blurry" and "distorted." The patient has been having vision problems over the past year, and these have made it more difficult to drive and require that he use a bright light to read the newspaper. He has no history of diabetes mellitus or hypertension. The patient uses an albuterol inhaler for occasional wheezing and shortness of breath. Ophthalmologic examination of the right eye shows a grayish discoloration of the macula with areas of adjacent hemorhage. Which of the following should be specifically targeted in treatment of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Vascular endothelial growth factor

questions.text: A 27-year-old man leaves the men's room of a bar after smoking an unknown substance. He soon becomes disoriented and belligerent. The man displays uncoordinated, jerky movements of his extremities and assaults a bouncer who tries to calm him. When police and emergency medical services personnel arrive, he fights off 4 officers before being restrained and appears immune to pain. In the emergency department, the patient has visual hallucinations, cannot cooperate with the interview, and alternates between agitation and sedation. He is hypertensive and tachycardic, and examination shows vertical nystagmus. Which of the following is the primary mechanism of action of the drug most likely used by this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor antagonism

 

This patient’s presentation — severe agitation, belligerence, violent behaviour, hallucinations, feeling immune to pain, hypertension, tachycardia, and the classic finding of vertical nystagmus — is most characteristic of phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication. PCP acts primarily as an NMDA receptor antagonist, leading to dissociative anaesthetic effects, agitation, psychosis, and nystagmus. These features strongly point toward PCP use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine receptor antagonism: This is the mechanism of action of antipsychotics, which reduce positive psychotic symptoms such as Delusion, Hallucination, Catatonia.

 

Option B. GABA-A receptor modulation: Benzodiazepines and barbiturates act through GABA-A receptors, leading to CNS depression, sedation, and anxiolysis. Intoxication typically causes slurred speech, ataxia, and somnolence, not violent agitation and nystagmus.

 

Option C. Mu-opioid receptor agonism: Opioids such as heroin and morphine act at mu receptors, producing euphoria, analgesia, miosis, and respiratory depression. They do not cause aggression, hallucinations, or vertical nystagmus.

choices.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

questions.text:
A woman presents with impaired hearing. Her audiometry findings are given below.

 

 

Pick the right combination of tuning fork test results that would be seen in this patient.
questions.solution: Ans. C) Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A 28-year-old obese female patient with schizophrenia is currently being treated with risperidone. She has recently developed galactorrhea. What should be the next step in her treatment?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Switch to aripiprazole

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with unilateral hardness of hearing and ear block sensation. Rinne was negative on affected side. Cone of light was absent and handle of malleus was foreshortened. On impedance audiometry, which of the following type of curve is most likely to appear?
questions.solution: Ans. C. C

choices.text: 2 and 3

questions.text:
Which of the following tests can be used if otoacoustic emissions is absent for screening?

 

  1. Pure tone audiometry
  2. Tympanometry
  3. Free field audiometry
  4. Speech audiometry
questions.solution: Ans. A. 2 and 4

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Illicit drug use
Prior seasonal allergies
Recent head trauma

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to persistent rhinorrhea. The patient has clear drainage from the right side of her nose that increases when she has a bowel movement or bends over to pick something off the floor. On examination, the external nose appears normal, the turbinates are pink, and the septum is straight. There is a small amount of clear fluid from her right nostril. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which of the following additional history is most important for establishing a diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. ﻿﻿﻿Recent head trauma

questions.text: Please identify the retractor depicted in the image below:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Mollisons Mastoid retractor

questions.text: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has minimally spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Stage IB

choices.text: It may lead to pugilistic ear
It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space
All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented at the hospital with a reported history of ear trauma. Upon examination, there was observed swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Resolves spontaneously

 

Auricular hematoma = collection of blood between the perichondrium and cartilage of the pinna due to trauma.


If not treated, it organizes into fibrous tissue and deforms the ear → cauliflower ear (pugilistic ear).

 

  • It does not resolve spontaneously. Instead, it requires drainage and compression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It may lead to pugilistic ear: true. Untreated hematoma causes fibrosis and cartilage distortion → cauliflower ear, typical in boxers/wrestlers.

 

Option B. It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: true. Trauma separates perichondrium from underlying cartilage, blood fills this space.

 

Option D. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics: true. Because cartilage has poor blood supply, hematomas are prone to infection and perichondritis. Prophylactic antistaphylococcal antibiotics are recommended.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of hypermature cataract presents with a 2 day history of ciliary congestion, photophobia, blurring of vision and on examination has a deep anterior chamber in the right eye. The left eye is normal. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Phacolytic glaucoma

choices.text: Adverse effect of antibiotic

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for right lower-lobe pneumonia. He is given antibiotics, and his shortness of breath and fever improve by the second hospital day. However, he now has new-onset abdominal pain, diarrhea, and severe muscle aches. Temperature is 36.8 C (98.2 F), blood pressure is 124/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 88/min. On examination, the patient appears uncomfortable and anxious. Pupils are dilated and there is prominent lacrimation. Abdominal examination reveals hyperactive bowel sounds without tenderness or distension. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Opioid withdrawal

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

  1. Schwalbe’s line corresponds to descemet’s membrane
  2. Brimonidine causes drowsiness
  3. Pupil that responds to convergence but light reflex is absent is known as Adie’s  pupil
  4. DCR drainage is seen in inferior meatus
questions.solution: Ans. B. 1, 2

questions.text: A 38-year-old man visits the clinic complaining of persistent daytime drowsiness, startling episodes of muscle weakness triggered by strong emotions, and terrifying hallucinations just as he is falling asleep or waking up. Which of the following symptoms does NOT typically belong to the characteristic symptomatology of narcolepsy?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Catalepsy

questions.text:
Following is a part of ethmoid bone?

 

  1. Inferior turbinate
  2. Middle turbinate
  3. Nasal bones
  4. Inferior spine on septum
questions.solution: Ans. B. 2

choices.text: Body dysmorphic disorder

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents due to concern about his development. The patient has had a long-standing interest in fashion and a preference for having girls as friends, and his parents noticed that he recently bought women's underwear and shoes and went out to meet friends wearing makeup. They worry that he is being bullied since moving to a new high school last year. When interviewed privately the patient says, "I have always wanted to be a girl." He is distressed that his voice is deepening and that he is developing facial and pubic hair, which he shaves regularly. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of this patient's behavior?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Gender dysphoria

questions.text: A 30-year-old school teacher presents with a three-day history of fever, chills, and sore throat. He also complains of difficulty swallowing that started yesterday. He denies any cough, chest pain, or difficulty breathing. His temperature is 39.8° C (102.2 F), blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 19/min. On examination, his voice is muffled. Enlarged, tender cervical lymph nodes are palpated on the left, and his uvula is deviated to the right. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Needle peritonsillar aspiration

 

This patient presents with fever, sore throat, dysphagia, muffled “hot potato” voice, tender cervical lymphadenopathy, and uvular deviation – classical signs of a peritonsillar abscess (quinsy).

 

  • The uvula deviates away from the side of the abscess due to tonsillar swelling.
  • The standard treatment is drainage of the abscess, which can be done by needle aspiration, incision and drainage, or tonsillectomy (quinsy tonsillectomy in select cases).
  • Needle aspiration is the first-line and most appropriate immediate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Throat swabs and oral antibiotics: This is insufficient. A peritonsillar abscess requires drainage; antibiotics alone cannot resolve the pus collection.

 

Option B. Monospot test and oral antibiotics: This is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis caused by EBV. The clinical picture here (uvular deviation, muffled voice) is more consistent with peritonsillar abscess, not mono.

 

Option C. Emergency laryngoscopy: Indicated in suspected airway obstruction, such as epiglottitis or severe laryngeal pathology. This patient has no stridor or severe respiratory distress, so laryngoscopy is not the initial step.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Trismus

choices.text: Begin administration of an antiarrhythmic medication

questions.text: A 46-year-old male, with a recent diagnosis of severe major depressive disorder, is brought to the emergency department by his wife. He is confused, lethargic, and his vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. His wife informs the healthcare team that she discovered an empty container of his tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) medication, raising concerns about an intentional overdose. The patient's ECG is performed and it shows widened QRS complexes. In this context, with a likely TCA overdose, what is the most suitable immediate intervention?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Administer Sodium Bicarbonate (NaHCO3)

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with bleeding from the throat 6 hours after undergoing a tonsillectomy. He is hemodynamically stable but appears anxious. On examination, there is fresh blood in the oropharynx. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his bleeding?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Reactionary hemorrhage

choices.text: External hordeolum is an acute inflammation of the Zeis gland
Internal hordeolum is an acute inflammation of the Zeis gland
Internal hordeolum is an acute suppurative inflammation of meibomian gland
Chalazion is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the meibornian gland

questions.text: Which of the following is false:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Internal hordeolum is an acute inflammation of the Zeis gland

choices.text: Adjustment disorder with anxiety
Delusional disorder (somatic subtype)
Illness anxiety disorder

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the office due to concerns about having pancreatic cancer after a coworker died of the disease 6 months ago. The patient has no epigastric pain, jaundice, or weight loss. However, he worries constantly because in researching the illness he read that it may not have obvious symptoms in early stages and can be rapidly fatal. The patient saw another physician 2 months ago, who performed a physical examination, laboratory evaluation, and abdominal CT scan. The results were normal and the physician reassured the patient that he did not have cancer. However, the patient reports that he has noticed occasional stomach noises after eating and would like to have additional testing done. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Illness anxiety disorder

questions.text: Which of these structures are retained during radical neck dissection?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Sublingual gland

questions.text: Foreign body entry into the laryngeal inlet is prevented by the cough reflex. This reflex is sluggish in alcohol ingestion and some other conditions. Which nerve is likely injured?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Internal laryngeal nerve

questions.text:
Find the true one among the following:

  1. Sampter triad – Asthma, Nasal polyposis (ethmoidal), bronchiectasis
  2. Kartagener syndrome – recurrent sinusitis, pleural effusion, infertility due to azoospermia
  3. Young syndrome – recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, infertility due to azoospermia
  4. Gradenigo’s triad – retro-orbital pain, diplopia, ear discharge
questions.solution: Ans. C) 3,4

choices.text: Separation anxiety disorder

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the OPD by his mother due to frequent nighttime awakenings. Over the past several months, the patient has had weekly episodes of waking up screaming at night. His mother says, "He seems fine when we're reading his bedtime story, but 1-2 hours after falling asleep, he wakes up shrieking. He looks scared, hyperventilates, and cries. When I try to hug him, he pushes me away and eventually falls back asleep." The mother is concerned that the patient is watching horror movies with his older brother; however, she mentions that the next morning he does not remember his dreams or having awakened. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Sleep terrors

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with worsening fever and sore throat. Four days ago, the patient accidentally swallowed a fish bone that scratched her throat and caused some discomfort. She felt better after some time and did not seek medical attention, but for the past 2 days she has had severe sore throat and difficulty swallowing. The patient also reports neck pain and stiffness. Examination shows pooling of saliva in the hypopharynx. The posterior pharyngeal wall is red and bulging. The neck is stiff with reduced passive range of motion. Lung auscultation is normal. Lateral radiographs of the neck reveal increased thickness of the prevertebral soft tissues with an air-fluid level. Due to potential contiguous spread of the disease process, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. ﻿A) Acute necrotizing mediastinitis

 

  • The scenario describes a classic case of retropharyngeal abscess, which can develop after a traumatic event such as swallowing a sharp foreign object that injures the posterior pharyngeal wall.
  • Findings: Severe sore throat, pooling of saliva, bulging posterior pharyngeal wall, neck pain, and prevertebral soft tissue swelling with air-fluid level on lateral neck X-ray are hallmark features of retropharyngeal abscess.
  • This abscess is located in the retropharyngeal space, which is anatomically continuous with the mediastinum via the "danger space" (between alar and prevertebral fascia). Because of this, infection can easily spread downward into the mediastinum, causing acute necrotizing mediastinitis, a life-threatening complication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cranial subdural empyema: Typically results from contiguous spread of sinusitis or otitis, not from retropharyngeal infections.

 

Option C. Ludwig angina: Involves the submandibular space, often originating from dental infections, not retropharyngeal abscess.

 

Option D. Septic cavernous sinus thrombosis: Most commonly occurs secondary to infections of the face, nose, or sinuses, not the posterior pharyngeal wall.

questions.text: Steroids are used in all except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Acute dacryocystitis

choices.text: Suicide following a minimal dose of a medication
Decreasing suicidal tendencies as her condition improves

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, who has been undergoing treatment for severe depression for the last few months, shows signs of improvement in her overall energy levels and daily functioning. However, she appears to still harbour some suicidal ideations. Her psychiatrist is particularly cautious during this phase of her recovery due to the risk of which of the following scenarios?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Paradoxical suicide

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of a progressively enlarging mass in his right nostril. He reports occasional bleeding from the nostril and a sense of nasal obstruction. He has a history of swimming in freshwater lakes. On examination, the following is noted in the right nasal cavity. Biopsy of the mass is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Sporangia containing numerous endospores

questions.text: A metal factory worker suffers from noise-induced hearing loss. Which of the following structures will be affected?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Outer hair cells

choices.text: Aggregations of phosphorylated tau protein
Cytoplasm inclusions with alpha synuclein
Cytosolic vacuolation of neurons and glia with prion inclusions
Extracellular deposition of beta-amyloid

questions.text: A 55-year-old, previously healthy man is brought to the OPD by his wife after being forced into early retirement due to poor work performance. The patient was a financial planner but began missing important deadlines and mismanaging his client's accounts 6 months ago. He became more irritable during this time and started to curse at and insult his coworkers when they expressed concern about his performance. The patient has also become verbally abusive toward his wife but appears indifferent to the hurt he causes. She has had to take over the finances and grocery shopping. She adds, "My husband has developed quite the sweet tooth. He eats almost two boxes of cookies a day now." Physical examination is unremarkable. This patient is most likely to have which of the following neuropathologic findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Aggregations of phosphorylated tau protein

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to her psychiatrist for a regular follow-up visit. She has been under treatment for major depressive disorder with Sertraline for the past three months. During the review of her symptoms, she reports experiencing some side effects from the medication. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with Sertraline?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Sialorrhea

questions.text: All are fundus findings of diabetic retinopathy except:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Arteriolar dilatation

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Ans. D. A4, B3, C2, D1

choices.text: Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder
Stereotypic movement disorder

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic due to unusual classroom behavior for the past year, which has worsened over the last few weeks. Although the patient is generally quiet, he intermittently disrupts the class with sniffling, repetitive throat clearing, and grunting sounds. His teacher states that the boy distracts other students and that his focus in class is poor. The behaviors worsen when he is tired, stressed, or excited. The patient's parents are also concerned because he has only a few friends and his classmates make fun of him. Medical history is significant for recurrent otitis media as a toddler, atopic dermatitis, and an influenza infection 9 months ago. Physical examination shows frequent eye blinking and shoulder shrugging but is otherwise normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. ﻿﻿D. Tourette syndrome

choices.text: Vertical direct contact

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the OPD due to hoarseness. The parents report that he has had worsening hoarseness for the past year, and his voice now sounds very raspy and rough. Flexible laryngoscopy is performed and shows bilateral lesions on the true vocal cords. Removal of these lesions is performed via direct laryngoscopy. Histopathologic analysis shows a fibrovascular core with benign squamous cells. The physician explains to the parents that this is likely due to a viral infection acquired through which of the following routes of transmission?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Vertical direct contact
